The night after I talked to these college girls, I also went to a men's group in Kansas, and these were exactly the kind of victims of the manufacturing economy which I spoke to you about earlier. They were men who had been contractors, or they had been building houses and they had lost their jobs after the housing boom, and they were in this group because they were failing to pay their child support. And the instructor was up there in the class explaining to them all the ways in which they had lost their identity in this new age. He was telling them they no longer had any moral authority, that nobody needed them for emotional support anymore, and they were not really the providers. So who were they? And this was very disheartening for them. And what he did was he wrote down on the board "$85,000," and he said, "That's her salary," and then he wrote down "$12,000." "That's your salary. So who's the man now?" he asked them. "Who's the damn man? She's the man now." And that really sent a shudder through the room. And that's part of the reason I like to talk about this, because I think it can be pretty painful, and we really have to work through it.And the other reason it's kind of urgent is because it's not just happening in the U.S. It's happening all over the world. In India, poor women are learning English faster than their male counterparts in order to staff the new call centers that are growing in India. In China, a lot of the opening up of private entrepreneurship is happening because women are starting businesses, small businesses, faster than men. And here's my favorite example, which is in South Korea. Over several decades, South Korea built one of the most patriarchal societies we know about. They basically enshrined the second-class status of women in the civil code. And if women failed to birth male children, they were basically treated like domestic servants. And sometimes family would pray to the spirits to kill off a girl child so they could have a male child. But over the '70s and '80s, the South Korea government decided they wanted to rapidly industrialize, and so what they did was, they started to push women into the workforce. Now they've been asking a question since 1985: "How strongly do you prefer a first-born son?" And now look at the chart. That's from 1985 to 2003. How much do you prefer a first-born son?So you can see that these economic changes really do have a strong effect on our culture. Now because we haven't fully processed this information, it's kind of coming back to us in our pop culture in these kind of weird and exaggerated ways, where you can see that the stereotypes are changing. And so we have on the male side what one of my colleagues likes to call the "omega males" popping up, who are the males who are romantically challenged losers who can't find a job. And they come up in lots of different forms. So we have the perpetual adolescent. We have the charmless misanthrope. Then we have our Bud Light guy who's the happy couch potato. And then here's a shocker: even America's most sexiest man alive, the sexiest man alive gets romantically played these days in a movie. And then on the female side, you have the opposite, in which you have these crazy superhero women. You've got Lady Gaga. You've got our new James Bond, who's Angelina Jolie. And it's not just for the young, right? Even Helen Mirren can hold a gun these days. And so it feels like we have to move from this place where we've got these uber-exaggerated images into something that feels a little more normal.So for a long time in the economic sphere, we've lived with the term "glass ceiling." Now I've never really liked this term. For one thing, it puts men and women in a really antagonistic relationship with one another, because the men are these devious tricksters up there who've put up this glass ceiling. And we're always below the glass ceiling, the women. And we have a lot of skill and experience, but it's a trick, so how are you supposed to prepare to get through that glass ceiling? And also, "shattering the glass ceiling" is a terrible phrase. What crazy person would pop their head through a glass ceiling?So the image that I like to think of, instead of glass ceiling, is the high bridge. It's definitely terrifying to stand at the foot of a high bridge, but it's also pretty exhilarating, because it's beautiful up there, and you're looking out on a beautiful view. And the great thing is there's no trick like with the glass ceiling. There's no man or woman standing in the middle about to cut the cables. There's no hole in the middle that you're going to fall through. And the great thing is that you can take anyone along with you. You can bring your husband along. You can bring your friends, or your colleagues, or your babysitter to walk along with you. And husbands can drag their wives across, if their wives don't feel ready. But the point about the high bridge is that you have to have the confidence to know that you deserve to be on that bridge, that you have all the skills and experience you need in order to walk across the high bridge, but you just have to make the decision to take the first step and do it.Thanks very much.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:14.958
We are now going through an amazing and unprecedented moment

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:16.958
where the power dynamics between men and women

00:00:16.958 --> 00:00:19.958
are shifting very rapidly,

00:00:19.958 --> 00:00:21.958
and in many of the places where it counts the most,

00:00:21.958 --> 00:00:24.958
women are, in fact, taking control of everything.

00:00:24.958 --> 00:00:26.958
In my mother's day, she didn't go to college.

00:00:26.958 --> 00:00:28.958
Not a lot of women did.

00:00:28.958 --> 00:00:31.958
And now, for every two men who get a college degree,

00:00:31.958 --> 00:00:33.958
three women will do the same.

00:00:33.958 --> 00:00:35.958
Women, for the first time this year,

00:00:35.958 --> 00:00:37.958
became the majority of the American workforce.

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:40.958
And they're starting to dominate lots of professions --

00:00:40.958 --> 00:00:42.958
doctors, lawyers,

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:44.958
bankers, accountants.

00:00:44.958 --> 00:00:47.958
Over 50 percent of managers are women these days,

00:00:47.958 --> 00:00:49.958
and in the 15 professions

00:00:49.958 --> 00:00:51.958
projected to grow the most in the next decade,

00:00:51.958 --> 00:00:53.958
all but two of them are dominated by women.

00:00:53.958 --> 00:00:55.958
So the global economy is becoming a place

00:00:55.958 --> 00:00:57.958
where women are more successful than men,

00:00:57.958 --> 00:00:59.958
believe it or not,

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:01.958
and these economic changes

00:01:01.958 --> 00:01:03.958
are starting to rapidly affect our culture --

00:01:03.958 --> 00:01:05.958
what our romantic comedies look like,

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:07.958
what our marriages look like,

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:09.958
what our dating lives look like,

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:11.958
and our new set of superheroes.

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:14.958
For a long time, this is the image of American manhood that dominated --

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:16.958
tough, rugged,

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:18.958
in control of his own environment.

00:01:18.958 --> 00:01:20.958
A few years ago, the Marlboro Man was retired

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:22.958
and replaced by this

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:24.958
much less impressive specimen,

00:01:24.958 --> 00:01:26.958
who is a parody of American manhood,

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:29.958
and that's what we have in our commercials today.

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:31.958
The phrase "first-born son"

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:34.958
is so deeply ingrained in our consciousness

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:36.958
that this statistic alone shocked me.

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:38.958
In American fertility clinics,

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:40.958
75 percent of couples

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:42.958
are requesting girls and not boys.

00:01:42.958 --> 00:01:44.958
And in places where you wouldn't think,

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:47.958
such as South Korea, India and China,

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:49.958
the very strict patriarchal societies

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:51.958
are starting to break down a little,

00:01:51.958 --> 00:01:53.958
and families are no longer

00:01:53.958 --> 00:01:56.958
strongly preferring first-born sons.

00:01:56.958 --> 00:01:59.958
If you think about this, if you just open your eyes to this possibility

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:01.958
and start to connect the dots,

00:02:01.958 --> 00:02:03.958
you can see the evidence everywhere.

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:05.958
You can see it in college graduation patterns,

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:07.958
in job projections,

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:09.958
in our marriage statistics,

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:12.958
you can see it in the Icelandic elections, which you'll hear about later,

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:15.958
and you can see it on South Korean surveys on son preference,

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:17.958
that something amazing and unprecedented

00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:19.958
is happening with women.

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:22.958
Certainly this is not the first time that we've had great progress with women.

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:25.958
The '20s and the '60s also come to mind.

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:27.958
But the difference is that, back then,

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:30.958
it was driven by a very passionate feminist movement

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:32.958
that was trying to project its own desires,

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:34.958
whereas this time, it's not about passion,

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:36.958
and it's not about any kind of movement.

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:38.958
This is really just about the facts

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:40.958
of this economic moment that we live in.

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:42.958
The 200,000-year period

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:44.958
in which men have been top dog

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:47.958
is truly coming to an end, believe it or not,

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:50.958
and that's why I talk about the "end of men."

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:52.958
Now all you men out there,

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:55.958
this is not the moment where you tune out or throw some tomatoes,

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:57.958
because the point is that this

00:02:57.958 --> 00:02:59.958
is happening to all of us.

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:02.958
I myself have a husband and a father

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:04.958
and two sons whom I dearly love.

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:06.958
And this is why I like to talk about this,

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:08.958
because if we don't acknowledge it,

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:10.958
then the transition will be pretty painful.

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:12.958
But if we do take account of it,

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:14.958
then I think it will go much more smoothly.

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:18.958
I first started thinking about this about a year and a half ago.

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:21.958
I was reading headlines about the recession just like anyone else,

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:23.958
and I started to notice a distinct pattern --

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:26.958
that the recession was affecting men

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:28.958
much more deeply than it was affecting women.

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:30.958
And I remembered back to about 10 years ago

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:33.958
when I read a book by Susan Faludi

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:36.958
called "Stiffed: The Betrayal of the American Man,"

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:39.958
in which she described how hard the recession had hit men,

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:41.958
and I started to think about

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:44.958
whether it had gotten worse this time around in this recession.

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:47.958
And I realized that two things were different this time around.

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:49.958
The first was that

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:51.958
these were no longer just temporary hits

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:53.958
that the recession was giving men --

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:55.958
that this was reflecting a deeper

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:57.958
underlying shift in our global economy.

00:03:57.958 --> 00:03:59.958
And second, that the story was no longer

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:01.958
just about the crisis of men,

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:03.958
but it was also about what was happening to women.

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:05.958
And now look at this second set of slides.

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:08.958
These are headlines about what's been going on with women in the next few years.

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:11.958
These are things we never could have imagined a few years ago.

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:13.958
Women, a majority of the workplace.

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:16.958
And labor statistics: women take up most managerial jobs.

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:18.958
This second set of headlines --

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:21.958
you can see that families and marriages are starting to shift.

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:23.958
And look at that last headline --

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:25.958
young women earning more than young men.

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:28.958
That particular headline comes to me from a market research firm.

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:31.958
They were basically asked by one of their clients

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:34.958
who was going to buy houses in that neighborhood in the future.

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:36.958
And they expected that it would be young families,

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:38.958
or young men, just like it had always been.

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:40.958
But in fact, they found something very surprising.

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:42.958
It was young, single women

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:45.958
who were the major purchasers of houses in the neighborhood.

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:48.958
And so they decided, because they were intrigued by this finding,

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:50.958
to do a nationwide survey.

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:52.958
So they spread out all the census data,

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:55.958
and what they found, the guy described to me as a shocker,

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:58.958
which is that in 1,997

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:00.958
out of 2,000 communities,

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:02.958
women, young women,

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:04.958
were making more money than young men.

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:06.958
So here you have a generation of young women

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:08.958
who grow up thinking of themselves

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:10.958
as being more powerful earners

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:12.958
than the young men around them.

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:15.958
Now, I've just laid out the picture for you,

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:18.958
but I still haven't explained to you why this is happening.

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:20.958
And in a moment, I'm going to show you a graph,

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:22.958
and what you'll see on this graph --

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:24.958
it begins in 1973,

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:26.958
just before women start flooding the workforce,

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:29.958
and it brings us up to our current day.

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:31.958
And basically what you'll see

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:33.958
is what economists talk about

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:35.958
as the polarization of the economy.

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:37.958
Now what does that mean?

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:40.958
It means that the economy is dividing into high-skill, high-wage jobs

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:42.958
and low-skill, low-wage jobs --

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:45.958
and that the middle, the middle-skill jobs,

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:48.958
and the middle-earning jobs, are starting to drop out of the economy.

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:50.958
This has been going on for 40 years now.

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:52.958
But this process is affecting men

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:54.958
very differently than it's affecting women.

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:57.958
You'll see the women in red, and you'll see the men in blue.

00:05:57.958 --> 00:06:00.958
You'll watch them both drop out of the middle class,

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:02.958
but see what happens to women and see what happens to men.

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:06.958
There we go.

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:09.958
So watch that. You see them both drop out of the middle class.

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:12.958
Watch what happens to the women. Watch what happens to the men.

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:14.958
The men sort of stagnate there,

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:16.958
while the women zoom up in those high-skill jobs.

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:18.958
So what's that about?

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:21.958
It looks like women got some power boost on a video game,

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:24.958
or like they snuck in some secret serum into their birth-control pills

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:26.958
that lets them shoot up high.

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:28.958
But of course, it's not about that.

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:31.958
What it's about is that the economy has changed a lot.

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:33.958
We used to have a manufacturing economy,

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:35.958
which was about building goods and products,

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:38.958
and now we have a service economy

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:40.958
and an information and creative economy.

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:43.958
Those two economies require very different skills,

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:45.958
and as it happens, women have been much better

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:48.958
at acquiring the new set of skills than men have been.

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:50.958
It used to be that you were

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:52.958
a guy who went to high school

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:54.958
who didn't have a college degree,

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:56.958
but you had a specific set of skills,

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:58.958
and with the help of a union,

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:00.958
you could make yourself a pretty good middle-class life.

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:02.958
But that really isn't true anymore.

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:04.958
This new economy is pretty indifferent

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:06.958
to size and strength,

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:08.958
which is what's helped men along all these years.

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:10.958
What the economy requires now

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:12.958
is a whole different set of skills.

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:14.958
You basically need intelligence,

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:17.958
you need an ability to sit still and focus,

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:19.958
to communicate openly,

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:21.958
to be able to listen to people

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:24.958
and to operate in a workplace that is much more fluid than it used to be,

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:26.958
and those are things that women do extremely well,

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:28.958
as we're seeing.

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:30.958
If you look at management theory these days,

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:32.958
it used to be that our ideal leader

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:34.958
sounded something like General Patton, right?

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:36.958
You would be issuing orders from above.

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:38.958
You would be very hierarchical.

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:40.958
You would tell everyone below you what to do.

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:42.958
But that's not what an ideal leader is like now.

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:44.958
If you read management books now,

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:47.958
a leader is somebody who can foster creativity,

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:50.958
who can get his -- get the employees -- see, I still say "his" --

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:52.958
who can get the employees to talk to each other,

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:55.958
who can basically build teams and get them to be creative.

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:58.958
And those are all things that women do very well.

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:01.958
And then on top of that, that's created a kind of cascading effect.

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
Women enter the workplace at the top,

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:05.958
and then at the working class,

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:07.958
all the new jobs that are created

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:10.958
are the kinds of jobs that wives used to do for free at home.

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:12.958
So that's childcare,

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:14.958
elder care and food preparation.

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:16.958
So those are all the jobs that are growing,

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:18.958
and those are jobs that women tend to do.

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:20.958
Now one day it might be

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:23.958
that mothers will hire an out-of-work,

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:25.958
middle-aged, former steelworker guy

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:27.958
to watch their children at home,

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:30.958
and that would be good for the men, but that hasn't quite happened yet.

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:33.958
To see what's going to happen, you can't just look at the workforce that is now,

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:36.958
you have to look at our future workforce.

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:39.958
And here the story is fairly simple.

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:41.958
Women are getting college degrees

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:43.958
at a faster rate than men.

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
Why? This is a real mystery.

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:48.958
People have asked men, why don't they just go back to college,

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:50.958
to community college, say, and retool themselves,

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:52.958
learn a new set of skills?

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:55.958
Well it turns out that they're just very uncomfortable doing that.

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:57.958
They're used to thinking of themselves as providers,

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:59.958
and they can't seem to build the social networks

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:01.958
that allow them to get through college.

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:03.958
So for some reason

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:05.958
men just don't end up going back to college.

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:07.958
And what's even more disturbing

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:09.958
is what's happening with younger boys.

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:11.958
There's been about a decade of research

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:13.958
about what people are calling the "boy crisis."

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
Now the boy crisis is this idea

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:18.958
that very young boys, for whatever reason,

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:21.958
are doing worse in school than very young girls,

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:23.958
and people have theories about that.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:25.958
Is it because we have an excessively verbal curriculum,

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:27.958
and little girls are better at that than little boys?

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:30.958
Or that we require kids to sit still too much,

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:32.958
and so boys initially feel like failures?

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:34.958
And some people say it's because,

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:36.958
in 9th grade, boys start dropping out of school.

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:39.958
Because I'm writing a book about all this, I'm still looking into it,

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:41.958
so I don't have the answer.

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:44.958
But in the mean time, I'm going to call on the worldwide education expert,

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:46.958
who's my 10-year-old daughter, Noa,

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:48.958
to talk to you about

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:51.958
why the boys in her class do worse.

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:53.958
(Video) Noa: The girls are obviously smarter.

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:56.958
I mean they have much larger vocabulary.

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:58.958
They learn much faster.

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:00.958
They are more controlled.

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:03.958
On the board today for losing recess tomorrow, only boys.

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:05.958
Hanna Rosin: And why is that?

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:07.958
Noa: Why? They were just not listening to the class

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:09.958
while the girls sat there very nicely.

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:11.958
HR: So there you go.

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:13.958
This whole thesis really came home to me

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:16.958
when I went to visit a college in Kansas City --

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:18.958
working-class college.

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:21.958
Certainly, when I was in college, I had certain expectations about my life --

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:24.958
that my husband and I would both work,

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:26.958
and that we would equally raise the children.

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:28.958
But these college girls

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:30.958
had a completely different view of their future.

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:33.958
Basically, the way they said it to me is

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:35.958
that they would be working 18 hours a day,

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:37.958
that their husband would maybe have a job,

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:40.958
but that mostly he would be at home taking care of the kiddies.

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:42.958
And this was kind of a shocker to me.

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:44.958
And then here's my favorite quote from one of the girls:

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:47.958
"Men are the new ball and chain."

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:50.958
(Laughter)

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:52.958
Now you laugh,

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:54.958
but that quote has kind of a sting to it, right?

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:56.958
And I think the reason it has a sting

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:58.958
is because thousands of years of history

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:00.958
don't reverse themselves

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:02.958
without a lot of pain,

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:04.958
and that's why I talk about

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:06.958
us all going through this together.

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:09.958
The night after I talked to these college girls,

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:11.958
I also went to a men's group in Kansas,

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:14.958
and these were exactly the kind of victims of the manufacturing economy

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:16.958
which I spoke to you about earlier.

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:18.958
They were men who had been contractors,

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:20.958
or they had been building houses

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:22.958
and they had lost their jobs after the housing boom,

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:25.958
and they were in this group because they were failing to pay their child support.

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:27.958
And the instructor was up there in the class

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:29.958
explaining to them all the ways

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:32.958
in which they had lost their identity in this new age.

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:35.958
He was telling them they no longer had any moral authority,

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:37.958
that nobody needed them for emotional support anymore,

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:39.958
and they were not really the providers.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
So who were they?

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:43.958
And this was very disheartening for them.

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:45.958
And what he did was he wrote down on the board

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:47.958
"$85,000,"

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:49.958
and he said, "That's her salary,"

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:52.958
and then he wrote down "$12,000."

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:54.958
"That's your salary.

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:56.958
So who's the man now?" he asked them.

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:58.958
"Who's the damn man?

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:00.958
She's the man now."

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:02.958
And that really sent a shudder through the room.

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:04.958
And that's part of the reason I like to talk about this,

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:06.958
because I think it can be pretty painful,

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:08.958
and we really have to work through it.

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:10.958
And the other reason it's kind of urgent

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:12.958
is because it's not just happening in the U.S.

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:14.958
It's happening all over the world.

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:16.958
In India, poor women are learning English

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:18.958
faster than their male counterparts

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:20.958
in order to staff the new call centers

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:22.958
that are growing in India.

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:25.958
In China, a lot of the opening up of private entrepreneurship

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:27.958
is happening because women are starting businesses,

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:29.958
small businesses, faster than men.

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:32.958
And here's my favorite example, which is in South Korea.

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:34.958
Over several decades,

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:37.958
South Korea built one of the most patriarchal societies we know about.

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:41.958
They basically enshrined the second-class status of women

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:43.958
in the civil code.

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:45.958
And if women failed to birth male children,

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:48.958
they were basically treated like domestic servants.

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:51.958
And sometimes family would pray to the spirits to kill off a girl child

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:53.958
so they could have a male child.

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:55.958
But over the '70s and '80s,

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:58.958
the South Korea government decided they wanted to rapidly industrialize,

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:00.958
and so what they did was,

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:02.958
they started to push women into the workforce.

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:05.958
Now they've been asking a question since 1985:

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:07.958
"How strongly do you prefer a first-born son?"

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:09.958
And now look at the chart.

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:12.958
That's from 1985 to 2003.

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:14.958
How much do you prefer a first-born son?

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:16.958
So you can see that these economic changes

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:19.958
really do have a strong effect on our culture.

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:22.958
Now because we haven't fully processed this information,

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
it's kind of coming back to us in our pop culture

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
in these kind of weird and exaggerated ways,

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:30.958
where you can see that the stereotypes are changing.

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:32.958
And so we have on the male side

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:35.958
what one of my colleagues likes to call the "omega males" popping up,

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:37.958
who are the males who are romantically challenged losers

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:39.958
who can't find a job.

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:42.958
And they come up in lots of different forms.

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:45.958
So we have the perpetual adolescent.

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:48.958
We have the charmless misanthrope.

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:50.958
Then we have our Bud Light guy

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:52.958
who's the happy couch potato.

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:55.958
And then here's a shocker: even America's most sexiest man alive,

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:57.958
the sexiest man alive

00:13:57.958 --> 00:13:59.958
gets romantically played these days in a movie.

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:02.958
And then on the female side, you have the opposite,

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:05.958
in which you have these crazy superhero women.

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:08.958
You've got Lady Gaga.

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:11.958
You've got our new James Bond, who's Angelina Jolie.

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:14.958
And it's not just for the young, right?

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:17.958
Even Helen Mirren can hold a gun these days.

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:20.958
And so it feels like we have to move from this place

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:23.958
where we've got these uber-exaggerated images

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:26.958
into something that feels a little more normal.

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:28.958
So for a long time in the economic sphere,

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:30.958
we've lived with the term "glass ceiling."

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:32.958
Now I've never really liked this term.

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:34.958
For one thing, it puts men and women

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:37.958
in a really antagonistic relationship with one another,

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:39.958
because the men are these devious tricksters up there

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:41.958
who've put up this glass ceiling.

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:44.958
And we're always below the glass ceiling, the women.

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:47.958
And we have a lot of skill and experience,

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:49.958
but it's a trick, so how are you supposed to prepare

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:51.958
to get through that glass ceiling?

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:54.958
And also, "shattering the glass ceiling" is a terrible phrase.

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:56.958
What crazy person

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:58.958
would pop their head through a glass ceiling?

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:00.958
So the image that I like to think of,

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:02.958
instead of glass ceiling,

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:04.958
is the high bridge.

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:07.958
It's definitely terrifying to stand at the foot of a high bridge,

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.958
but it's also pretty exhilarating,

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:11.958
because it's beautiful up there,

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:14.958
and you're looking out on a beautiful view.

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:17.958
And the great thing is there's no trick like with the glass ceiling.

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:19.958
There's no man or woman standing in the middle

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:21.958
about to cut the cables.

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:23.958
There's no hole in the middle that you're going to fall through.

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:26.958
And the great thing is that you can take anyone along with you.

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:28.958
You can bring your husband along.

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:30.958
You can bring your friends, or your colleagues,

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:32.958
or your babysitter to walk along with you.

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:35.958
And husbands can drag their wives across, if their wives don't feel ready.

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:37.958
But the point about the high bridge

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:39.958
is that you have to have the confidence

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:41.958
to know that you deserve to be on that bridge,

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:44.958
that you have all the skills and experience you need

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:47.958
in order to walk across the high bridge,

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:49.958
but you just have to make the decision

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:51.958
to take the first step and do it.

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:53.958
Thanks very much.

00:15:53.958 --> 00:16:02.958
(Applause)

title: How to learn? From mistakes
transcript: I have been teaching for a long time, and in doing so have acquired a body of knowledge about kids and learning that I really wish more people would understand about the potential of students. In 1931, my grandmother — bottom left for you guys over here — graduated from the eighth grade. She went to school to get the information because that's where the information lived. It was in the books; it was inside the teacher's head; and she needed to go there to get the information, because that's how you learned. Fast-forward a generation: this is the one-room schoolhouse, Oak Grove, where my father went to a one-room schoolhouse. And he again had to travel to the school to get the information from the teacher, stored it in the only portable memory he has, which is inside his own head, and take it with him, because that is how information was being transported from teacher to student and then used in the world. When I was a kid, we had a set of encyclopedias at my house. It was purchased the year I was born, and it was extraordinary, because I did not have to wait to go to the library to get to the information. The information was inside my house and it was awesome. This was different than either generation had experienced before, and it changed the way I interacted with information even at just a small level. But the information was closer to me. I could get access to it.In the time that passes between when I was a kid in high school and when I started teaching, we really see the advent of the Internet. Right about the time that the Internet gets going as an educational tool, I take off from Wisconsin and move to Kansas, small town Kansas, where I had an opportunity to teach in a lovely, small-town, rural Kansas school district, where I was teaching my favorite subject, American government. My first year — super gung-ho — going to teach American government, loved the political system. Kids in the 12th grade: not exactly all that enthusiastic about the American government system. Year two: learned a few things — had to change my tactic. And I put in front of them an authentic experience that allowed them to learn for themselves. I didn't tell them what to do or how to do it. I posed a problem in front of them, which was to put on an election forum for their own community.They produced flyers. They called offices. They checked schedules. They were meeting with secretaries. They produced an election forum booklet for the entire town to learn more about their candidates. They invited everyone into the school for an evening of conversation about government and politics and whether or not the streets were done well, and really had this robust experiential learning. The older teachers — more experienced — looked at me and went, "Oh, there she is. That's so cute. She's trying to get that done." (Laughter) "She doesn't know what she's in for." But I knew that the kids would show up, and I believed it, and I told them every week what I expected out of them. And that night, all 90 kids — dressed appropriately, doing their job, owning it. I had to just sit and watch. It was theirs. It was experiential. It was authentic. It meant something to them. And they will step up.From Kansas, I moved on to lovely Arizona, where I taught in Flagstaff for a number of years, this time with middle school students. Luckily, I didn't have to teach them American government. Could teach them the more exciting topic of geography. Again, "thrilled" to learn. But what was interesting about this position I found myself in in Arizona, was I had this really extraordinarily eclectic group of kids to work with in a truly public school, and we got to have these moments where we would get these opportunities. And one opportunity was we got to go and meet Paul Rusesabagina, which is the gentleman that the movie "Hotel Rwanda" is based after. And he was going to speak at the high school next door to us. We could walk there. We didn't even have to pay for the buses. There was no expense cost. Perfect field trip.The problem then becomes how do you take seventh- and eighth-graders to a talk about genocide and deal with the subject in a way that is responsible and respectful, and they know what to do with it. And so we chose to look at Paul Rusesabagina as an example of a gentleman who singularly used his life to do something positive. I then challenged the kids to identify someone in their own life, or in their own story, or in their own world, that they could identify that had done a similar thing. I asked them to produce a little movie about it. It's the first time we'd done this. Nobody really knew how to make these little movies on the computer, but they were into it. And I asked them to put their own voice over it. It was the most awesome moment of revelation that when you ask kids to use their own voice and ask them to speak for themselves, what they're willing to share. The last question of the assignment is: how do you plan to use your life to positively impact other people? The things that kids will say when you ask them and take the time to listen is extraordinary.Fast-forward to Pennsylvania, where I find myself today. I teach at the Science Leadership Academy, which is a partnership school between the Franklin Institute and the school district of Philadelphia. We are a nine through 12 public school, but we do school quite differently. I moved there primarily to be part of a learning environment that validated the way that I knew that kids learned, and that really wanted to investigate what was possible when you are willing to let go of some of the paradigms of the past, of information scarcity when my grandmother was in school and when my father was in school and even when I was in school, and to a moment when we have information surplus. So what do you do when the information is all around you? Why do you have kids come to school if they no longer have to come there to get the information?In Philadelphia we have a one-to-one laptop program, so the kids are bringing in laptops with them everyday, taking them home, getting access to information. And here's the thing that you need to get comfortable with when you've given the tool to acquire information to students, is that you have to be comfortable with this idea of allowing kids to fail as part of the learning process. We deal right now in the educational landscape with an infatuation with the culture of one right answer that can be properly bubbled on the average multiple choice test, and I am here to share with you: it is not learning. That is the absolute wrong thing to ask, to tell kids to never be wrong. To ask them to always have the right answer doesn't allow them to learn. So we did this project, and this is one of the artifacts of the project. I almost never show them off because of the issue of the idea of failure.My students produced these info-graphics as a result of a unit that we decided to do at the end of the year responding to the oil spill. I asked them to take the examples that we were seeing of the info-graphics that existed in a lot of mass media, and take a look at what were the interesting components of it, and produce one for themselves of a different man-made disaster from American history. And they had certain criteria to do it. They were a little uncomfortable with it, because we'd never done this before, and they didn't know exactly how to do it. They can talk — they're very smooth, and they can write very, very well, but asking them to communicate ideas in a different way was a little uncomfortable for them. But I gave them the room to just do the thing. Go create. Go figure it out. Let's see what we can do. And the student that persistently turns out the best visual product did not disappoint. This was done in like two or three days. And this is the work of the student that consistently did it.And when I sat the students down, I said, "Who's got the best one?" And they immediately went, "There it is." Didn't read anything. "There it is." And I said, "Well what makes it great?" And they're like, "Oh, the design's good, and he's using good color. And there's some ... " And they went through all that we processed out loud. And I said, "Go read it." And they're like, "Oh, that one wasn't so awesome." And then we went to another one — it didn't have great visuals, but it had great information — and spent an hour talking about the learning process, because it wasn't about whether or not it was perfect, or whether or not it was what I could create. It asked them to create for themselves, and it allowed them to fail, process, learn from. And when we do another round of this in my class this year, they will do better this time, because learning has to include an amount of failure, because failure is instructional in the process.There are a million pictures that I could click through here, and had to choose carefully — this is one of my favorites — of students learning, of what learning can look like in a landscape where we let go of the idea that kids have to come to school to get the information, but instead, ask them what they can do with it. Ask them really interesting questions. They will not disappoint. Ask them to go to places, to see things for themselves, to actually experience the learning, to play, to inquire. This is one of my favorite photos, because this was taken on Tuesday, when I asked the students to go to the polls. This is Robbie, and this was his first day of voting, and he wanted to share that with everybody and do that. But this is learning too, because we asked them to go out into real spaces.The main point is that, if we continue to look at education as if it's about coming to school to get the information and not about experiential learning, empowering student voice and embracing failure, we're missing the mark. And everything that everybody is talking about today isn't possible if we keep having an educational system that does not value these qualities, because we won't get there with a standardized test, and we won't get there with a culture of one right answer. We know how to do this better, and it's time to do better.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:14.958
I have been teaching for a long time,

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:16.958
and in doing so

00:00:16.958 --> 00:00:19.958
have acquired a body of knowledge about kids and learning

00:00:19.958 --> 00:00:22.958
that I really wish more people would understand

00:00:22.958 --> 00:00:25.958
about the potential of students.

00:00:25.958 --> 00:00:27.958
In 1931, my grandmother --

00:00:27.958 --> 00:00:29.958
bottom left for you guys over here --

00:00:29.958 --> 00:00:31.958
graduated from the eighth grade.

00:00:31.958 --> 00:00:33.958
She went to school to get the information

00:00:33.958 --> 00:00:35.958
because that's where the information lived.

00:00:35.958 --> 00:00:37.958
It was in the books; it was inside the teacher's head;

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:40.958
and she needed to go there to get the information,

00:00:40.958 --> 00:00:42.958
because that's how you learned.

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:44.958
Fast-forward a generation:

00:00:44.958 --> 00:00:46.958
this is the one-room schoolhouse, Oak Grove,

00:00:46.958 --> 00:00:48.958
where my father went to a one-room schoolhouse.

00:00:48.958 --> 00:00:50.958
And he again had to travel to the school

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:52.958
to get the information from the teacher,

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:55.958
stored it in the only portable memory he has, which is inside his own head,

00:00:55.958 --> 00:00:57.958
and take it with him,

00:00:57.958 --> 00:01:00.958
because that is how information was being transported

00:01:00.958 --> 00:01:03.958
from teacher to student and then used in the world.

00:01:03.958 --> 00:01:05.958
When I was a kid,

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:07.958
we had a set of encyclopedias at my house.

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:09.958
It was purchased the year I was born,

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:11.958
and it was extraordinary,

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:14.958
because I did not have to wait to go to the library to get to the information.

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:16.958
The information was inside my house

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:18.958
and it was awesome.

00:01:18.958 --> 00:01:20.958
This was different

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:22.958
than either generation had experienced before,

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:24.958
and it changed the way I interacted with information

00:01:24.958 --> 00:01:26.958
even at just a small level.

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:28.958
But the information was closer to me.

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:30.958
I could get access to it.

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:32.958
In the time that passes

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:34.958
between when I was a kid in high school

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:36.958
and when I started teaching,

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:38.958
we really see the advent of the Internet.

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:40.958
Right about the time that the Internet gets going

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:42.958
as an educational tool,

00:01:42.958 --> 00:01:44.958
I take off from Wisconsin

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:46.958
and move to Kansas, small town Kansas,

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:48.958
where I had an opportunity to teach

00:01:48.958 --> 00:01:50.958
in a lovely, small-town,

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:52.958
rural Kansas school district,

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:54.958
where I was teaching my favorite subject,

00:01:54.958 --> 00:01:56.958
American government.

00:01:56.958 --> 00:01:59.958
My first year -- super gung-ho -- going to teach American government,

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:01.958
loved the political system.

00:02:01.958 --> 00:02:03.958
Kids in the 12th grade:

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:05.958
not exactly all that enthusiastic

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:07.958
about the American government system.

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:10.958
Year two: learned a few things -- had to change my tactic.

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:12.958
And I put in front of them an authentic experience

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:15.958
that allowed them to learn for themselves.

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:17.958
I didn't tell them what to do or how to do it.

00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:19.958
I posed a problem in front of them,

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:22.958
which was to put on an election forum for their own community.

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:25.958
They produced flyers. They called offices.

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:27.958
They checked schedules. They were meeting with secretaries.

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:29.958
They produced an election forum booklet

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:31.958
for the entire town to learn more about their candidates.

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:33.958
They invited everyone into the school

00:02:33.958 --> 00:02:35.958
for an evening of conversation

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:37.958
about government and politics

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:39.958
and whether or not the streets were done well,

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:42.958
and really had this robust experiential learning.

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:44.958
The older teachers -- more experienced --

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:46.958
looked at me and went,

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:49.958
"Oh, there she is. That's so cute. She's trying to get that done."

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:51.958
(Laughter)

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:53.958
"She doesn't know what she's in for."

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:55.958
But I knew that the kids would show up,

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:57.958
and I believed it,

00:02:57.958 --> 00:03:00.958
and I told them every week what I expected out of them.

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:02.958
And that night, all 90 kids --

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:05.958
dressed appropriately, doing their job, owning it.

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:07.958
I had to just sit and watch.

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:09.958
It was theirs. It was experiential. It was authentic.

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:11.958
It meant something to them.

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:13.958
And they will step up.

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:16.958
From Kansas, I moved on to lovely Arizona,

00:03:16.958 --> 00:03:19.958
where I taught in Flagstaff for a number of years,

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:21.958
this time with middle school students.

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:23.958
Luckily, I didn't have to teach them American government.

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:26.958
Could teach them the more exciting topic of geography.

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:29.958
Again, "thrilled" to learn.

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:32.958
But what was interesting

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:35.958
about this position I found myself in in Arizona,

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:37.958
was I had this really

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:39.958
extraordinarily eclectic group of kids to work with

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:41.958
in a truly public school,

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:44.958
and we got to have these moments where we would get these opportunities.

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:46.958
And one opportunity

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:49.958
was we got to go and meet Paul Rusesabagina,

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:51.958
which is the gentleman

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:53.958
that the movie "Hotel Rwanda" is based after.

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:55.958
And he was going to speak at the high school next door to us.

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:57.958
We could walk there. We didn't even have to pay for the buses.

00:03:57.958 --> 00:04:00.958
There was no expense cost. Perfect field trip.

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:02.958
The problem then becomes

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:04.958
how do you take seventh- and eighth-graders to a talk about genocide

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:06.958
and deal with the subject in a way

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:08.958
that is responsible and respectful,

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:10.958
and they know what to do with it.

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:12.958
And so we chose to look at Paul Rusesabagina

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:14.958
as an example of a gentleman

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:18.958
who singularly used his life to do something positive.

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:20.958
I then challenged the kids to identify

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:23.958
someone in their own life, or in their own story, or in their own world,

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:25.958
that they could identify that had done a similar thing.

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:27.958
I asked them to produce a little movie about it.

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:29.958
It's the first time we'd done this.

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:31.958
Nobody really knew how to make these little movies on the computer,

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:34.958
but they were into it. And I asked them to put their own voice over it.

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:40.958
It was the most awesome moment of revelation

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:43.958
that when you ask kids to use their own voice

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:45.958
and ask them to speak for themselves,

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:47.958
what they're willing to share.

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:49.958
The last question of the assignment is:

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:51.958
how do you plan to use your life

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:53.958
to positively impact other people?

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:55.958
The things that kids will say

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:58.958
when you ask them and take the time to listen

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:01.958
is extraordinary.

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:04.958
Fast-forward to Pennsylvania, where I find myself today.

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:06.958
I teach at the Science Leadership Academy,

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:09.958
which is a partnership school between the Franklin Institute

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:11.958
and the school district of Philadelphia.

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:14.958
We are a nine through 12 public school,

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:17.958
but we do school quite differently.

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:19.958
I moved there primarily

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:21.958
to be part of a learning environment

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:23.958
that validated the way that I knew that kids learned,

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:25.958
and that really wanted to investigate

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:27.958
what was possible

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:29.958
when you are willing to let go

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:31.958
of some of the paradigms of the past,

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:34.958
of information scarcity when my grandmother was in school

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:37.958
and when my father was in school and even when I was in school,

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:39.958
and to a moment when we have information surplus.

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:42.958
So what do you do when the information is all around you?

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:44.958
Why do you have kids come to school

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:47.958
if they no longer have to come there to get the information?

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:50.958
In Philadelphia we have a one-to-one laptop program,

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:53.958
so the kids are bringing in laptops with them everyday,

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:56.958
taking them home, getting access to information.

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:59.958
And here's the thing that you need to get comfortable with

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:01.958
when you've given the tool

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:03.958
to acquire information to students,

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:05.958
is that you have to be comfortable with this idea

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:07.958
of allowing kids to fail

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:10.958
as part of the learning process.

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:12.958
We deal right now in the educational landscape

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:14.958
with an infatuation

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:16.958
with the culture of one right answer

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:19.958
that can be properly bubbled on the average multiple choice test,

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:21.958
and I am here to share with you:

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:23.958
it is not learning.

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:26.958
That is the absolute wrong thing to ask,

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:28.958
to tell kids to never be wrong.

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:31.958
To ask them to always have the right answer

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:33.958
doesn't allow them to learn.

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:35.958
So we did this project,

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:37.958
and this is one of the artifacts of the project.

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:39.958
I almost never show them off

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:41.958
because of the issue of the idea of failure.

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:43.958
My students produced these info-graphics

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:46.958
as a result of a unit that we decided to do at the end of the year

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:48.958
responding to the oil spill.

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:51.958
I asked them to take the examples that we were seeing

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:53.958
of the info-graphics that existed

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:55.958
in a lot of mass media,

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:58.958
and take a look at what were the interesting components of it,

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:00.958
and produce one for themselves

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:02.958
of a different man-made disaster from American history.

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:04.958
And they had certain criteria to do it.

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:06.958
They were a little uncomfortable with it,

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:08.958
because we'd never done this before, and they didn't know exactly how to do it.

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:10.958
They can talk -- they're very smooth,

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:12.958
and they can write very, very well,

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:15.958
but asking them to communicate ideas in a different way

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:18.958
was a little uncomfortable for them.

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:21.958
But I gave them the room to just do the thing.

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:23.958
Go create. Go figure it out.

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:25.958
Let's see what we can do.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:27.958
And the student that persistently

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:30.958
turns out the best visual product did not disappoint.

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:32.958
This was done in like two or three days.

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:35.958
And this is the work of the student that consistently did it.

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:38.958
And when I sat the students down, I said, "Who's got the best one?"

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:40.958
And they immediately went, "There it is."

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:42.958
Didn't read anything. "There it is."

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:44.958
And I said, "Well what makes it great?"

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:46.958
And they're like, "Oh, the design's good, and he's using good color.

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:49.958
And there's some ... " And they went through all that we processed out loud.

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:51.958
And I said, "Go read it."

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:54.958
And they're like, "Oh, that one wasn't so awesome."

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:56.958
And then we went to another one --

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:58.958
it didn't have great visuals, but it had great information --

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:01.958
and spent an hour talking about the learning process,

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
because it wasn't about whether or not it was perfect,

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:05.958
or whether or not it was what I could create.

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:08.958
It asked them to create for themselves,

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:10.958
and it allowed them to fail,

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:12.958
process, learn from.

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:14.958
And when we do another round of this in my class this year,

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:16.958
they will do better this time,

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:18.958
because learning

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:21.958
has to include an amount of failure,

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:23.958
because failure is instructional

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:25.958
in the process.

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:28.958
There are a million pictures

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:30.958
that I could click through here,

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:33.958
and had to choose carefully -- this is one of my favorites --

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:35.958
of students learning,

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:37.958
of what learning can look like

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:40.958
in a landscape where we let go of the idea

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:42.958
that kids have to come to school to get the information,

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:44.958
but instead, ask them what they can do with it.

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:46.958
Ask them really interesting questions.

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:48.958
They will not disappoint.

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:50.958
Ask them to go to places,

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:52.958
to see things for themselves,

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:54.958
to actually experience the learning,

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:57.958
to play, to inquire.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:59.958
This is one of my favorite photos,

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:01.958
because this was taken on Tuesday,

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:03.958
when I asked the students to go to the polls.

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:06.958
This is Robbie, and this was his first day of voting,

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:08.958
and he wanted to share that with everybody and do that.

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:10.958
But this is learning too,

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:13.958
because we asked them to go out into real spaces.

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:18.958
The main point

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:21.958
is that, if we continue to look at education

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:24.958
as if it's about coming to school

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:26.958
to get the information

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:28.958
and not about experiential learning,

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:31.958
empowering student voice and embracing failure,

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:33.958
we're missing the mark.

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:35.958
And everything that everybody is talking about today

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:38.958
isn't possible if we keep having an educational system

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:41.958
that does not value these qualities,

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:43.958
because we won't get there with a standardized test,

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:45.958
and we won't get there with a culture of one right answer.

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:47.958
We know how to do this better,

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:49.958
and it's time to do better.

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:54.958
(Applause)

title: Let's talk parenting taboos
transcript: Alisa Volkman: So this is where our story begins — the dramatic moments of the birth of our first son, Declan. Obviously a really profound moment, and it changed our lives in many ways. It also changed our lives in many unexpected ways, and those unexpected ways we later reflected on, that eventually spawned a business idea between the two of us, and a year later, we launched Babble, a website for parents.Rufus Griscom: Now I think of our story as starting a few years earlier. AV: That's true.RG: You may remember, we fell head over heels in love.AV: We did.RG: We were at the time running a very different kind of website. It was a website called Nerve.com, the tagline of which was "literate smut." It was in theory, and hopefully in practice, a smart online magazine about sex and culture.AV: That spawned a dating site. But you can understand the jokes that we get. Sex begets babies. You follow instructions on Nerve and you should end up on Babble, which we did. And we might launch a geriatric site as our third. We'll see.RG: But for us, the continuity between Nerve and Babble was not just the life stage thing, which is, of course, relevant, but it was really more about our desire to speak very honestly about subjects that people have difficulty speaking honestly about. It seems to us that when people start dissembling, people start lying about things, that's when it gets really interesting. That's a subject that we want to dive into. And we've been surprised to find, as young parents, that there are almost more taboos around parenting than there are around sex.AV: It's true. So like we said, the early years were really wonderful, but they were also really difficult. And we feel like some of that difficulty was because of this false advertisement around parenting. (Laughter) We subscribed to a lot of magazines, did our homework, but really everywhere you look around, we were surrounded by images like this. And we went into parenting expecting our lives to look like this. The sun was always streaming in, and our children would never be crying. I would always be perfectly coiffed and well rested, and in fact, it was not like that at all.RG: When we lowered the glossy parenting magazine that we were looking at, with these beautiful images, and looked at the scene in our actual living room, it looked a little bit more like this. These are our three sons. And of course, they're not always crying and screaming, but with three boys, there's a decent probability that at least one of them will not be comporting himself exactly as he should.AV: Yes, you can see where the disconnect was happening for us. We really felt like what we went in expecting had nothing to do with what we were actually experiencing, and so we decided we really wanted to give it to parents straight. We really wanted to let them understand what the realities of parenting were in an honest way.RG: So today, what we would love to do is share with you four parenting taboos. And of course, there are many more than four things you can't say about parenting, but we would like to share with you today four that are particularly relevant for us personally. So the first, taboo number one: you can't say you didn't fall in love with your baby in the very first minute. I remember vividly, sitting there in the hospital. We were in the process of giving birth to our first child.AV: We, or I?RG: I'm sorry. Misuse of the pronoun. Alisa was very generously in the process of giving birth to our first child — (AV: Thank you.) — and I was there with a catcher's mitt. And I was there with my arms open. The nurse was coming at me with this beautiful, beautiful child, and I remember, as she was approaching me, the voices of friends saying, "The moment they put the baby in your hands, you will feel a sense of love that will come over you that is [on] an order of magnitude more powerful than anything you've ever experienced in your entire life." So I was bracing myself for the moment. The baby was coming, and I was ready for this Mack truck of love to just knock me off my feet. And instead, when the baby was placed in my hands, it was an extraordinary moment. This picture is from literally a few seconds after the baby was placed in my hands and I brought him over. And you can see, our eyes were glistening. I was overwhelmed with love and affection for my wife, with deep, deep gratitude that we had what appeared to be a healthy child. And it was also, of course, surreal. I mean, I had to check the tags and make sure. I was incredulous, "Are you sure this is our child?" And this was all quite remarkable. But what I felt towards the child at that moment was deep affection, but nothing like what I feel for him now, five years later.And so we've done something here that is heretical. We have charted our love for our child over time. (Laughter) This, as you know, is an act of heresy. You're not allowed to chart love. The reason you're not allowed to chart love is because we think of love as a binary thing. You're either in love, or you're not in love. You love, or you don't love. And I think the reality is that love is a process, and I think the problem with thinking of love as something that's binary is that it causes us to be unduly concerned that love is fraudulent, or inadequate, or what have you. And I think I'm speaking obviously here to the father's experience. But I think a lot of men do go through this sense in the early months, maybe their first year, that their emotional response is inadequate in some fashion.AV: Well, I'm glad Rufus is bringing this up, because you can notice where he dips in the first years where I think I was doing most of the work. But we like to joke, in the first few months of all of our children's lives, this is Uncle Rufus. (Laughter)RG: I'm a very affectionate uncle, very affectionate uncle.AV: Yes, and I often joke with Rufus when he comes home that I'm not sure he would actually be able to find our child in a line-up amongst other babies. So I actually threw a pop quiz here onto Rufus.RG: Uh oh.AV: I don't want to embarrass him too much. But I am going to give him three seconds.RG: That is not fair. This is a trick question. He's not up there, is he?AV: Our eight-week-old son is somewhere in here, and I want to see if Rufus can actually quickly identify him.RG: The far left. AV: No!(Laughter)RG: Cruel.AV: Nothing more to be said.(Laughter)I'll move on to taboo number two. You can't talk about how lonely having a baby can be. I enjoyed being pregnant. I loved it. I felt incredibly connected to the community around me. I felt like everyone was participating in my pregnancy, all around me, tracking it down till the actual due-date. I felt like I was a vessel of the future of humanity. That continued into the the hospital. It was really exhilarating. I was shower with gifts and flowers and visitors. It was a really wonderful experience, but when I got home, I suddenly felt very disconnected and suddenly shut in and shut out, and I was really surprised by those feelings. I did expect it to be difficult, have sleepless nights, constant feedings, but I did not expect the feelings of isolation and loneliness that I experienced, and I was really surprised that no one had talked to me, that I was going to be feeling this way. And I called my sister whom I'm very close to — and had three children — and I asked her, "Why didn't you tell me I was going to be feeling this way, that I was going to have these — feeling incredibly isolated?" And she said — I'll never forget — "It's just not something you want to say to a mother that's having a baby for the first time."RG: And of course, we think it's precisely what you really should be saying to mothers who have kids for the first time. And that this, of course, one of the themes for us is that we think that candor and brutal honesty is critical to us collectively being great parents. And it's hard not to think that part of what leads to this sense of isolation is our modern world. So Alisa's experience is not isolated. So your 58 percent of mothers surveyed report feelings of loneliness. Of those, 67 percent are most lonely when their kids are zero to five — probably really zero to two. In the process of preparing this, we looked at how some other cultures around the world deal with this period of time, because here in the Western world, less than 50 percent of us live near our family members, which I think is part of why this is such a tough period. So to take one example among many: in Southern India there's a practice known as jholabhari, in which the pregnant woman, when she's seven or eight months pregnant, moves in with her mother and goes through a series of rituals and ceremonies, give birth and returns home to her nuclear family several months after the child is born. And this is one of many ways that we think other cultures offset this kind of lonely period.AV: So taboo number three: you can't talk about your miscarriage — but today I'll talk about mine. So after we had Declan, we kind of recalibrated our expectations. We thought we actually could go through this again and thought we knew what we would be up against. And we were grateful that I was able to get pregnant, and I soon learned that we were having a boy, and then when I was five months, we learned that we had lost our child. This is actually the last little image we have of him. And it was obviously a very difficult time — really painful. As I was working through that mourning process, I was amazed that I didn't want to see anybody. I really wanted to crawl into a hole, and I didn't really know how I was going to work my way back into my surrounding community. And I realize, I think, the way I was feeling that way, is on a really deep gut level, I was feeling a lot of shame and embarrassed, frankly, that, in some respects, I had failed at delivering what I'm genetically engineered to do. And of course, it made me question, if I wasn't able to have another child, what would that mean for my marriage, and just me as a woman. So it was a very difficult time. As I started working through it more, I started climbing out of that hole and talking with other people. I was really amazed by all the stories that started flooding in. People I interacted with daily, worked with, was friends with, family members that I had known a long time, had never shared with me their own stories. And I just remember feeling all these stories came out of the woodwork, and I felt like I happened upon this secret society of women that I now was a part of, which was reassuring and also really concerning. And I think, miscarriage is an invisible loss. There's not really a lot of community support around it. There's really no ceremony, rituals, or rites. And I think, with a death, you have a funeral, you celebrate the life, and there's a lot of community support, and it's something women don't have with miscarriage.RG: Which is too bad because, of course, it's a very common and very traumatic experience. Fifteen to 20 percent of all pregnancies result in miscarriage, and I find this astounding. In a survey, 74 percent of women said that miscarriage, they felt, was partly their fault, which is awful. And astoundingly, 22 percent said they would hide a miscarriage from their spouse.So taboo number four: you can't say that your average happiness has declined since having a child. The party line is that every single aspect of my life has just gotten dramatically better ever since I participated in the miracle that is childbirth and family. I'll never forget, I remember vividly to this day, our first son, Declan, was nine months old, and I was sitting there on the couch, and I was reading Daniel Gilbert's wonderful book, "Stumbling on Happiness." And I got about two-thirds of the way through, and there was a chart on the right-hand side — on the right-hand page — that we've labeled here "The Most Terrifying Chart Imaginable for a New Parent." This chart is comprised of four completely independent studies. Basically, there's this precipitous drop of marital satisfaction, which is closely aligned, we all know, with broader happiness, that doesn't rise again until your first child goes to college. So I'm sitting here looking at the next two decades of my life, this chasm of happiness that we're driving our proverbial convertible straight into. We were despondent.AV: So you can imagine, I mean again, the first few months were difficult, but we'd come out of it, and were really shocked to see this study. So we really wanted to take a deeper look at it in hopes that we would find a silver lining.RG: And that's when it's great to be running a website for parents, because we got this incredible reporter to go and interview all the scientists who conducted these four studies. We said, something is wrong here. There's something missing from these studies. It can't possibly be that bad. So Liz Mitchell did a wonderful job with this piece, and she interviewed four scientists, and she also interviewed Daniel Gilbert, and we did indeed find a silver lining. So this is our guess as to what this baseline of average happiness arguably looks like throughout life. Average happiness is, of course, inadequate, because it doesn't speak to the moment-by-moment experience, and so this is what we think it looks like when you layer in moment-to-moment experience. And so we all remember as children, the tiniest little thing — and we see it on the faces of our children — the teeniest little thing can just rocket them to these heights of just utter adulation, and then the next teeniest little thing can cause them just to plummet to the depths of despair. And it's just extraordinary to watch, and we remember it ourselves. And then, of course, as you get older, it's almost like age is a form of lithium.As you get older, you become more stable. And part of what happens, I think, in your '20s and '30s, is you start to learn to hedge your happiness. You start to realize that "Hey, I could go to this live music event and have an utterly transforming experience that will cover my entire body with goosebumps, but it's more likely that I'll feel claustrophobic and I won't be able to get a beer. So I'm not going to go. I've got a good stereo at home. So, I'm not going to go." So your average happiness goes up, but you lose those transcendent moments.AV: Yeah, and then you have your first child, and then you really resubmit yourself to these highs and lows — the highs being the first steps, the first smile, your child reading to you for the first time — the lows being, our house, any time from six to seven every night. But you realize you resubmit yourself to losing control in a really wonderful way, which we think provides a lot of meaning to our lives and is quite gratifying.RG: And so in effect, we trade average happiness. We trade the sort of security and safety of a certain level of contentment for these transcendent moments. So where does that leave the two of us as a family with our three little boys in the thick of all this? There's another factor in our case. We have violated yet another taboo in our own lives, and this is a bonus taboo.AV: A quick bonus taboo for you, that we should not be working together, especially with three children — and we are.RG: And we had reservations about this on the front end. Everybody knows, you should absolutely not work with your spouse. In fact, when we first went out to raise money to start Babble, the venture capitalists said, "We categorically don't invest in companies founded by husbands and wives, because there's an extra point of failure. It's a bad idea. Don't do it." And we obviously went forward. We did. We raised the money, and we're thrilled that we did, because in this phase of one's life, the incredibly scarce resource is time. And if you're really passionate about what you do every day — which we are — and you're also passionate about your relationship, this is the only way we know how to do it. And so the final question that we would ask is: can we collectively bend that happiness chart upwards? It's great that we have these transcendent moments of joy, but they're sometimes pretty quick. And so how about that average baseline of happiness? Can we move that up a little bit?AV: And we kind of feel that the happiness gap, which we talked about, is really the result of walking into parenting — and really any long-term partnership for that matter — with the wrong expectations.
